context.p: As for the custom login and logout modules, you need to analyze the existing functionality of your application and adapt it to match the required behavior.

provides resources for J2EE environments that support you in adapting the login/logout implementation of a Java-based Web application. The resources are called integration helpers and contain a ready-to-use token handler and logout listener.
The integration helpers can be used with any Java-based Web application. The token handler is implemented as a Java servlet and as a JSP; the logout listener is implemented as a session listener.
If your application is based on a different technology, you need to implement your own token handler and logout listener by calling the following methods of the platform Session Service (see ):

ul.li: resolveUserToken for requesting to resolve a user token
deleteServiceSession for notifying of a logout or session timeout

context.p: The following figure illustrates how login access works and which parts have to be added or adapted in the login/logout implementation of your application (components provided by including the integration helpers are shown in gray):
The integration helpers are contained in the integrationhelper subfolder of the integration package (oscm-integration-pack):

ul.li: oscm-webservices-proxy.jar: A library containing a Web service proxy for BASIC Web service ports of the platform services. This proxy is implemented in Java and ready to be used. It creates a Web service proxy containing all information required to establish a connection with a Web service.
Integrationhelper.jar: A library containing a token handler and logout listener. They are also implemented in Java and ready to be used.

oscm-api-client-handler.jar: A library containing a SOAP handler for adding a service version number to the outbound SOAP messages of a Web service client. The service version can be found in the <documentation> tag included in the WSDL files.
Integrationhelper.war: A Web archive including the above integration helpers and additional resources required by them.
IntegrationhelperSRC.zip: An archive file containing the source code of the integration helpers.

context.p: The Integrationhelper.war package has the following contents:

row.entry: Token handler, welcome, and logout page implemented as Java server pages (JSP), as well as a page for testing Web service calls.
A sample servlet configuration for the integration of a token handler and a logout listener in a custom Web application.
A folder containing all JAR files required by the integration helpers.
A folder containing the ready-to-use logout listener class:LogoutListener.class, as well as the ready-to-use token handler class: TokenHandler.class.
A property file specifying the relative URL to the custom login module of your application. The custom login module must be on the same machine and in the same context as the token handler.
A property file specifying the information needed to access the platform services.

p.b: To integrate the integration helpers into your Web application:

step.cmd: Extract the Integrationhelper.war package from the integration package to a location of your choice, or add the Integrationhelper.jar and oscm-webservices-proxy.jar packages to the class path of your application.
Configure the webserviceclient.properties file and enter the following information:

ul.li: Server and port where the platform services have been deployed.

The URL of the WSDL file of the platform's Session Service.
The Web service port of a platform service is BASIC.
ID or key as well as password of the calling user. The user must have the role of a technology manager in a technology provider organization.

step.cmd: Configure the tokenhandler.properties file and specify the relative URL to the custom login module of your application. The custom login module must be on the same machine and in the same context as the token handler.
Copy the contents of the WEB-INF/lib and WEB-INF/classes folders to the corresponding folders of your Web application.

choices.choice: If you want to use the JSP-based token handler, copy the Tokenhandler.jsp file to your Web application.

If you want to use the servlet-based token handler, register it in the web.xml file of your Web application.
To do this, you can copy the servlet and servlet-mapping sections from the sample web.xml file, which is part of the Integrationhelper.war package, to the web.xml file of your Web application.

step.cmd: Register the logout listener in the web.xml file of your Web application.

info.p: To do this, you can copy the listener section from the sample web.xml file, which is part of the Integrationhelper.war package, to the web.xml file of your Web application.

step.cmd: In the technical service definition of the application, the path to the token handler must be specified in the loginPath attribute for login access.

info.p: For details on the technical service definition, refer to the Technology Provider's Guide.

example.title: Example
example.p: Suppose you implemented a servlet-based custom login module for your application, which is to be called after the user token has been resolved. The custom login module is available as a Web resource as a DoAutoLoginServlet servlet at /DoAutoLogin. Your Web application is running on myserver at port 7777 using the context myapplication. The platform services are listening at port 8081. is installed in SAML_SP mode.
Depending on whether you use the servlet-based or the JSP-based token handler, the configuration files look as shown below:

li.codeblock:
# Machine where Catalog Manager is hosted and port to access the web # service
cm.host=localhost cm.port=8081
# Catalog Manager web services are available on 3 different web # service ports (endpoints), # depending on the Catalog Manager authentication mode. # # Example - Web service port URLs for the Catalog Manager session # service: # https://localhost:8081/SessionService/BASIC?wsdl # https://localhost:8081/SessionService/CLIENTCERT?wsdl # https://localhost:8081/SessionService/STS?wsdl&tenantID=xxxxxxxx # # Set the web service port suffix, depending on the Catalog Manager # authentication mode: # - authentication mode INTERNAL: use BASIC or CLIENTCERT # - authentication mode SAML-SP : use STS
cm.service.port=BASIC
# Catalog Manager web service version
cm.service.version=v1.9
# User credentials to access Catalog Manager web service. # User key is used for BASIC and CLIENTCERT ports, and user ID # and tenant ID for STS port.
cm.service.user.key=1000 cm.service.user.id=administrator cm.service.user.password=<user_password> cm.service.user.tenantID=<tenant_ID>

ul.li: Technical service definition... <TechnicalService id="SampleService" baseUrl="https://myserver:7777/myservice" loginPath="/resolveToken" ... > ...
